quiz_set_1.question: Which practical device is attributed to a woman's ingenuity?
quiz_set_1.short_story:
Marie Van Brittan Brown – Home Security Systems (1966, USA)

Living in a high-crime neighborhood, Marie Van Brittan Brown often felt unsafe at home. But instead of waiting for better protection, she invented it—the first home security system, complete with cameras, two-way microphones, and a remote-controlled lock. Wiring together a complex setup at home was no small feat, especially with limited technology and resources. Some doubted whether her idea would take off, but her system laid the groundwork for modern surveillance. Today, her innovation protects homes, businesses, and millions of lives around the world.

quiz_set_1.question: Groundbreaking physics theorem - woman mathematician's principle on symmetries and what laws?
quiz_set_1.short_story:
Emmy Noether – Noether’s Theorem (1918, Germany)

While studying the deep connections in physics, Emmy Noether noticed a hidden pattern—symmetry wasn’t just beauty, it was law. Her groundbreaking Noether’s Theorem proved that every symmetry in nature corresponds to a conservation law—for example, the fact that energy never disappears comes from the symmetry of time. Despite being more brilliant than many of her male peers, she wasn’t allowed to hold a paid university position for years. Today, her work is fundamental in everything from quantum mechanics to relativity, shaping the very way we understand the universe.

quiz_set_1.question: Woman's ingenuity - which kitchen item?
quiz_set_1.short_story:
Melitta Bentz – Coffee Filter (1908, Germany)

In her small German kitchen, Melitta Bentz grew frustrated with bitter, gritty coffee. Experimenting with blotting paper from her son’s notebook, she crafted the first drip coffee filter, solving the problem of over-extraction. As a housewife, no one expected her invention to matter, but she patented it and built a thriving business. Today, coffee lovers worldwide rely on her method for a smooth, clean brew every morning.
quiz_set_1.fun_fact_comment: That smooth, delicious brew?  Give thanks to Melitta Bentz and her amazing coffee filter – women's smarts make everyday joys even better!

quiz_set_2.question: Which of these was pioneered by a woman mathematician?
quiz_set_2.short_story:
Ada Lovelace – The Woman Who Saw the Future (1843, England)

In 1843, Ada Lovelace looked at Charles Babbage’s Analytical Engine and saw something no one else did—a machine that could think beyond numbers. She wrote the world’s first computer algorithm, laying the foundation for modern programming. Yet, in a world that dismissed women in science, her genius was largely ignored. Today, every software, every program, and every digital breakthrough traces back to her vision—one that was ahead of its time, but never truly lost.

quiz_set_2.question: Which of these surgical technologies is credited to a woman inventor?
quiz_set_2.short_story:
Patricia Bath – Restoring Sight, Changing Lives (1986, USA)

As a young opthalmologist, Patricia Bath saw too many people losing their sight simply because they lacked access to proper care. Determined to change that, she invented the Laserphaco Probe in 1986, using lasers for safer, more precise and painless cataract removal. But as a Black woman in medicine, she faced constant resistance. Still, she persisted, and her invention has restored vision for millions, making modern eye surgery safer and more effective.

quiz_set_2.question: Which of these automotive features was notably commercialized through a woman's invention?
quiz_set_2.short_story:
Mary Anderson – A Clear Vision for Safer Roads (1903, USA)

On a cold day in 1903, Mary Anderson watched a trolley driver struggle to see through his snow-covered windshield. There had to be a better way, she thought. She designed the first automatic windshield wipers, a simple yet revolutionary solution. But when she pitched it, manufacturers laughed, calling it useless. Years later, when cars became faster and weather less forgiving, her invention became standard in every car, proving that sometimes, the world just takes a while to catch up.
quiz_set_2.fun_fact_comment: Next time you switch on your windshield wipers in a downpour, remember Mary Anderson - women innovators keep us safe and see clearly, even in the 'stormiest' situations of life!

quiz_set_3.question: Which of these was pioneered by a woman astronomer?
quiz_set_3.short_story:
Annie Jump Cannon – The Woman Who Organized the Stars (1901, USA)

In a time when women weren’t seen as scientists, Annie Jump Cannon quietly rewrote astronomy. In 1901, she developed the Harvard Classification System, organizing over 350,000 stars by temperature, characteristics and brightness—providing a fundamental framework for astrophysics and our understanding of stellar evolution. Despite being deaf and overlooked for years, she persevered, proving that while stars may burn out, legacies do not.

quiz_set_3.question: Which of these energy theories is credited to a woman physicist?
quiz_set_3.short_story:
Lise Meitner – The Forgotten Mind Behind Nuclear Fission (1938, Germany/Austria)

Fleeing Nazi persecution, Lise Meitner left everything behind—except her brilliance. In 1938, while in exile, she solved the mystery of nuclear fission, explaining how splitting atoms unleashed massive energy. But while Otto Hahn received the Nobel Prize, her name was erased from history’s spotlight. Yet her discovery reshaped science, energy, and the course of the world.

quiz_set_3.question: Which of these popular games has origins in a woman's design?
quiz_set_3.short_story:
Elizabeth Magie – The Game That Warned of Greed (1903, USA)

Elizabeth Magie believed games could teach powerful lessons. In 1903, she designed The Landlord’s Game, warning about the dangers of monopolies. She wanted to show how wealth concentrated in the hands of a few could crush the many. But as irony would have it, her idea was later commercialized into Monopoly, stripping away her message. Its lesson remains—some win big, while others go bankrupt trying.
quiz_set_3.fun_fact_comment: Next time you bankrupt your friends in Monopoly, remember Elizabeth Magie - women's games can be both fun AND teach you about economics, even if accidentally!

quiz_set_4.question: Which of these communication technologies is rooted in a woman's innovative concept?
quiz_set_4.short_story:
Hedy Lamarr – Spread Spectrum Technology (1941, USA)

By day, Hedy Lamarr was a glamorous Hollywood actress, but by night, she was an inventor. During World War II, she developed spread spectrum technology, a way to prevent enemies from jamming radio signals. But she was far ahead of her time—the military dismissed her invention as too complex. Decades later, her work became the foundation for Wi-Fi, GPS, and Bluetooth, proving that her genius reached far beyond the silver screen.

quiz_set_4.question: Which of these newborn assessments is credited to a woman physician?
quiz_set_4.short_story:
Dr. Virginia Apgar – Apgar Score (1952, USA)

Dr. Virginia Apgar saw too many newborns struggling in their first moments of life, and doctors had no standard way to assess them quickly. So she devised the Apgar Score, a simple yet lifesaving test that checks a baby’s health in the first critical minutes. As a woman in medicine, she often had to fight to be heard, but her system became the global standard. Today, every newborn is given this test, saving millions of lives.

quiz_set_4.question: Woman's ingenuity - which office supply for error correction?
quiz_set_4.short_story:
Bette Nesmith Graham – Liquid Paper (1956, USA)

As a secretary, Bette Nesmith Graham knew one mistake on a typewritten page meant starting over. Frustrated, she experimented with white tempera paint to cover errors, creating Liquid Paper. But no one took her seriously—after all, what did a secretary know about innovation? She kept refining it in her kitchen until it became a must-have in every office. Today, her invention has saved countless hours (and careers) from messy typos.
quiz_set_4.fun_fact_comment: Hit backspace today? Bette Nesmith Graham's Liquid Paper spirit lives on in every digital 'undo' – women's fixes keep evolving with us!

quiz_set_5.question: Astrophysical sensation - woman astronomer's discovery of which celestial objects?
quiz_set_5.short_story:
Jocelyn Bell Burnell – Discovery of Pulsars (1967, UK)

As a graduate student analyzing radio signals, Jocelyn Bell Burnell noticed an odd, rhythmic pulse from deep space—something never seen before. Many dismissed it as interference, but she persisted and discovered pulsars, rapidly spinning neutron stars. Though her male supervisor won the Nobel Prize, her discovery reshaped astrophysics, leading to advancements in gravitational waves and space-time research.

quiz_set_5.question: Which of these is a woman's discovery about what chromosomal event?
quiz_set_5.short_story:
Nettie Stevens – Non-Disjunction in Chromosomes (1905, USA) 

 While examining mealworm cells, Nettie Stevens uncovered a fundamental truth—sex is determined by chromosomes, not environmental factors as previously thought. Her work also revealed how errors in chromosome separation (non-disjunction) could lead to genetic disorders. Despite her breakthrough, credit often went to male colleagues. Today, her discovery shapes genetics, prenatal testing, and our understanding of inherited conditions.

quiz_set_5.question: Woman's ingenuity - which kitchen item?
quiz_set_5.short_story:
Lillian Moller Gilbreth – Foot-Pedal Trash Can (1920s, USA) 

 In the 1920s, industrial psychologist Lillian Moller Gilbreth observed how busy homemakers and surgeons struggled with opening trash bins while working. Applying her expertise in efficiency and ergonomics, she designed the foot-pedal trash can, allowing for hands-free use. Despite resistance to women in engineering, her inventions revolutionized household and workplace ergonomics. Today, her design is a staple in homes, hospitals, and public spaces, proving that small conveniences can create lasting change.
quiz_set_5.fun_fact_comment: Next time your hands are full, be grateful to Lillian Moller Gilbreth for an extra foot to help us all, one sweet step at a time!

quiz_set_6.question: Which of these Early computing was done by women programmers?
options: Harvard Mark I Relay Computer Team
quiz_set_6.short_story:
ENIAC Programmers – First Computer Programmers (1940s, USA) 

 During World War II, six brilliant women—Jean Bartik, Betty Snyder, and their team—were tasked with programming the ENIAC, the world’s first general-purpose computer. With no manuals or prior examples, they had to invent programming itself, manually wiring circuits to run complex wartime calculations. Though their work helped advance ballistics and early computing, they were long overlooked. Today, their legacy proves that modern software engineering started with women.

quiz_set_6.question: Transformative medical treatment - woman scientist pioneered use of what for cancer therapy?
quiz_set_6.short_story:
Marie Curie – Medical Use of Radioisotopes (1900s, France/Poland)

In the early 1900s, Marie Curie’s discovery of radium and polonium led to an unexpected breakthrough—radiation could shrink tumors. Hospitals soon began experimenting with radiotherapy for cancer patients, a treatment that became widely used by the 1920s. Despite facing skepticism and severe radiation exposure, Curie pushed forward, becoming the first person to win two Nobel Prizes. Today, millions of cancer patients owe their treatment to her pioneering work.

quiz_set_6.question: Everyday design upgrade - woman inventor's improvement to which common container?
quiz_set_6.short_story:
Margaret E. Knight – Modern Paper Bag (Flat-Bottom Design) (1870, USA)

In the late 19th century, grocery stores and factories relied on flimsy envelope-style paper bags that couldn’t hold much. Margaret E. Knight, working in a paper mill, designed a flat-bottom bag machine, making bags more stable and efficient for daily use. When she tried to patent it in 1871, a man stole her design, claiming that a woman couldn’t invent such a machine—but she won her case in court. Today, her sturdy bag design is still used worldwide, proving her innovation stood the test of time.
quiz_set_6.fun_fact_comment: Next time you carry groceries in a paper bag, remember Margaret Knight making carrying things easier for us all, one flat bottom at a time!

quiz_set_7.question: Which 'celestial event' is linked to the achievements of the first American woman astronomer?
quiz_set_7.short_story:
Maria Mitchell – First American Woman Astronomer (1847, USA)

One night in 1847, Maria Mitchell looked through her telescope and saw something no one else had—a new comet. It earned her international fame, but recognition didn’t come easy. Despite her sharp mind, she had to fight for a place in astronomy, a field dominated by men. Still, she became America’s first female professional astronomer, paving the way for women in science. Today, “Miss Mitchell’s Comet” remains a symbol of discovery, curiosity, and breaking barriers.

quiz_set_7.question: Which of these technologies for is credited to a woman physicist?
quiz_set_7.short_story:
Katharine Burr Blodgett – Non-Reflective Glass Coating (1938, USA)

Katharine Burr Blodgett spent years in the lab, frustrated by how glare and reflections ruined everything from photographs to telescopes. Her breakthrough came in 1938 when she developed non-reflective glass, making crystal-clear lenses possible. As the first woman to earn a physics PhD at Cambridge, she often had to prove her expertise, but her invention changed industries. Today, from camera lenses to car windshields, we see the world more clearly because of her.

quiz_set_7.question: Which pet accessory improvisation was done by a woman?
quiz_set_7.short_story:
Mary A. Delaney – Retractable Dog Leash (1908, USA)

Walking a dog used to be a constant tug-of-war—too much slack, too little control. Mary A. Delaney, a dog lover herself, wanted a solution. So, in 1908, she patented the first retractable leash, giving dogs freedom while keeping them safe. Some dismissed it as unnecessary, but any pet owner today would disagree. Her simple yet brilliant invention is now a must-have for dog lovers worldwide.
quiz_set_7.fun_fact_comment: Next time you enjoy an easy dog walk, remember women inventors making our lives better, one sweet touch at a time!**

quiz_set_8.question: Breakthrough burn treatment – which skin technology pioneered by a woman scientist?
quiz_set_8.short_story:
Fiona Wood – Spray-On Skin for Burn Victims (1990s, Australia)

As a surgeon, Fiona Wood saw firsthand how burns devastated patients, often leaving them with painful scars and slow healing. Determined to change this, she developed Spray-On Skin, a groundbreaking treatment that used a patient’s own cells to rapidly regenerate damaged skin. Some doubted it would work, but when a horrific accident left hundreds injured, her innovation saved lives. Today, her technique has revolutionized burn treatment, offering faster recovery and hope to countless patients.

quiz_set_8.question: Which cosmic phenomenon's discovery is attributed to a woman astronomer's meticulous observations?
quiz_set_8.short_story:
Vera Rubin – Uncovering Dark Matter (1970s, USA)

Staring at the night sky, Vera Rubin noticed something strange—galaxies weren’t moving the way they should. The numbers didn’t add up, leading her to confirm the existence of dark matter, an invisible force shaping the universe. Despite facing years of skepticism in a male-dominated field, she kept pushing for answers, proving her findings beyond doubt. Now, her discovery is one of the greatest mysteries in astrophysics, changing how we understand the cosmos.

quiz_set_8.question: Which of these home conveniences relies on a woman's clever mechanical design?
quiz_set_8.short_story:
Josephine Cochrane – Inventing the Practical Dishwasher (1886, USA)

Ater too many broken dishes at dinner parties, Josephine Cochrane had enough. Frustrated by careless servants chipping her fine china, she designed the first practical mechanical dishwasher, using water pressure instead of scrubbing. But as a woman in the 19th century, no one took her seriously—until hotels and restaurants saw its brilliance. Today, her invention is a household essential, saving time (and dishes) in kitchens worldwide.
quiz_set_8.fun_fact_comment: Next time you load up your dishwasher, remember Josephine Cochrane making kitchen clean-up easier for us all, one sweet touch at a time!

quiz_set_9.question: Which internert protocol was invented by a woman?
quiz_set_9.short_story:
Radia Perlman – Spanning Tree Protocol (1985, USA)

While working on complex computer networks, Radia Perlman kept running into the same frustrating issue—loops that caused entire systems to crash. Determined to fix it, she designed Spanning Tree Protocol (STP), a solution that let data find its way without getting stuck. But as one of the few women in her field, she often found herself explaining her own genius to those who doubted her. Today, her invention keeps the internet stable, making seamless global communication possible.

quiz_set_9.question: Which of the below cycle was a woman's discovery?
quiz_set_9.short_story:
Gerty Cori – Discovery of the Cori Cycle (1929, USA)

Gerty Cori was fascinated by how muscles burn energy and recover. Through relentless research, she uncovered the Cori Cycle, explaining how the body converts stored energy during exertion. Despite her groundbreaking work, she was often pushed into assistant roles while her male peers advanced, but she persisted—becoming the first American woman to win a Nobel Prize in Medicine. Today, her discovery is essential in understanding metabolism and diseases like diabetes.

quiz_set_9.question: Which skate design was improved by a woman fashion icon?
quiz_set_9.short_story:
Madeleine Vionnet – Quad Skate Design Improvement (1910s, France)

adeleine Vionnet loved roller skating but found existing skates clunky and hard to control. Applying her design skills, she refined the quad skate, allowing for smoother turns and better balance. Many dismissed her ideas, as she was better known for fashion than engineering, but her improvements revolutionized skating. Today, her design remains the foundation for modern roller skates, seen everywhere from rinks to roller derbies.
quiz_set_9.fun_fact_comment: Next time you lace up roller skates, remember Madeleine Vionnet making fun on wheels smoother for us all, one stylish design at a time!
